title: Randolph Peters
text:
Randolph Peters (born 28 December 1959) is a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> <a href="composer">composer</a> who is known for his output of roughly 100 <a href="film%20score">film score</a>s made mostly for Canadian films.
Early life and education.
Peters was born in <a href="Winnipeg">Winnipeg</a>, <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a>. He graduated from the <a href="University%20of%20Winnipeg">University of Winnipeg</a> and the <a href="Jacobs%20School%20of%20Music">Jacobs School of Music</a> at <a href="Indiana%20University">Indiana University</a>.
Career.
Peters wrote a large amount of music for Canadian television, radio, dance and theatre. From 1996 to 2001 he was the composer-in-residence and curator for the <a href="Winnipeg%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Winnipeg Symphony Orchestra</a>; he also served as the director of that symphony's annual New Music Festival.
Peters composed several <a href="opera">opera</a>s for the <a href="Canadian%20Opera%20Company">Canadian Opera Company</a>, of which the most successful was "<a href="The%20Golden%20Ass%20%28opera%29">The Golden Ass</a>", which was created with novelist <a href="Robertson%20Davies">Robertson Davies</a> shortly before Davies' death. After Davies' death, COC director Richard Bradshaw worked with Peters to finalize the opera. The opera premiered in Toronto at the Hummingbird Centre in April, 1999.
